headline.main: Babies Are Larger After Ban On 2 Pesticides, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study finds that pregnant women in upper Manhattan who were heavily exposed to two common insecticides had smaller babies than their neighbors, but that babies' size increased after restrictions were placed on substances: chlorpyrifos and diazinon; study is part of long-running project by Columbia University researchers to gauge effects of urban pollution on mothers and children (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women in upper Manhattan who were heavily exposed to two common insecticides had smaller babies than their neighbors, but recent restrictions on the two substances quickly lowered exposure and increased babies' size, according to a study being published today. The researchers, led by a team from Columbia University, looked at babies born to women living in Harlem and Washington Heights, and divided them into four groups, based on the amounts of the pesticides chlorpyrifos and diazinon found in the mothers' blood and umbilical cord blood. In the group with the highest levels, babies averaged 6.6 ounces lighter and one-third of an inch shorter than those in the group with no measurable amount of the insecticides in the blood.
